title: Friendly reminder that you agreed to Riot.
body:
No, this post wasn't written in the basement of a neckbeard.

When creating an account, the first thing they ask you to do, accepts the terms of service and the summoners code.

and with you agreeing to all this, Riot can deem your actions bannable or not.

Sometimes its not bannable, you had an off game, or you were first timing a hard champion, things happen.

But saying that Riot can't ban you because you bought 900 skins is wrong,  because you are an honorable player is wrong.

Riot can ban you, if they believe you are doing things that you agreed not to.

trolls do get banned.

boosters do get banned.

Everyone gets banned if they break the rules.

something you think is bannable, could not be, an off-meta build/champ/role, a player feeding his ass off because half the enemy team is somehow always ambushing him, is not intentional.

and typing requires you to think about what you are going to say and type that fully in
as opposed to speaking in real life, where words can come out that you didn't want to.

that concludes the post that won't change anything. 
because no one is going to read this before they post

replies.body:
80% of the playerbase probably hasn't even read the Terms of Use.

...Myself included.
Same. I just assume that the ToU says "don't be a dick".

I've read through it.

And, honestly? That's actually about half of it.

40% of it is generic game shit related to how League is *their* intellectual property and all that, how the currency in it has no real-world value, and how you don't own anything in it, even if you do "buy" it, because it's "bought" with something that's not a valid currency.

10% is them being a bit more specific, and also telling you to "please not" give Riot your ideas, but if you do give them them, they have full control over them, and can use them without license. Basically, if you put it on any server they own, they can keep it. Mostly, this is just the above, but also funnier.

And the other 50% boils down to "If you be a jackass we can remove you. Hell, we can remove you even if we can't *prove* you're being a jackass, but everyone knows it anyways".
Not valid currency? It seems pretty valid when it's leaving your credit card bruh...

Riot, and DuskDaUmbreon mean that when you purchase RP with cash/credit, the transaction is considered complete when the RP is credited to your account. The RP is stated to have no external value and to not be a valid currency.

This gets rid of accusations of "failure to deliver" or other fraud related crimes when a skin that you "purchased" is changed, a champion you "purchased" is reworked, or when an account is banned.
This is why I haven't financially supported them in years. They can take that logic and pack it in their ass.

Would you rather have Riot be legally unable to modify champions? Once someone purchased it, Riot would be unable to change it.

Also, once someone purchased a champion, no one else would be able to also purchase that champion. Someone already owns it.

Can you imagine League with 150 million different champions, many of which are in a completely overpowered state, like release Zoe?
What are you babbling about? No one can edit a champion. Who is going into Riot's servers and crafting custom champions? Do you know how intellectual property works?

Yes, I do know how IP works, and that includes the laws governing it.

I am saying, very specifically, that if Riot "sold" a character to a player, in the same manner that a desk is sold to someone, that Riot would not be allowed to change any of that character's abilities or visuals. No one is allowed to come into my house to modify or paint a desk that I own.

Also, if I "owned" a character in the same manner that I own my desk, then other people would be unable to use it. It is my desk.

With these two things, Riot would have to create a multitude of characters, so that people who wanted to play would be allowed to play. It's very hard to play a game of League without a champion. Many of these champions would be broken. Either "broken" meaning filled with bugs that it would take way too much man-hours to fix...and wait, they're not allowed to change things anyway, or "broken" meaning completely overpowered, as many champions are upon release, since they would be unable to patch them back into a reasonable state.

You are VERY wrong. By that logic anyone that buys a copy of Windows owns Windows? C'mon man use your head. You assume that people have access to Riot servers? Do you? Because I sure don't out side of the client. That's not how it works. People have a reasonable expectation to have access to goods after paying their "real" money for Riot's "fake money".

When you buy a "copy of Windows" you very much do not own a copy of Windows. What you have purchased is a limited license to use Windows. This is one of the basic differences between physical items and digital items. This is why the laws are different for those categories.

Why do you keep on bringing up players accessing or modifying Riot Servers? I have said nothing to even hint at that as an action.

What I have said is that: 
a) If a player OWNED a champion using the laws for physical objects, then no one else would be allowed to use or modify it.
b) That means that Riot would be unable to sell any champion to more than one player.
c) Riot would also be unable to modify any of their code, because that would be owned by the player who purchased it.
d) Because players need to have a champion to play the game, Riot would need to create a vast swarm of characters. They would need at least one character per player, but people would get really bored with only one character, so the number of characters would be huge.
e) With this vast swarm of characters that Riot is not allowed to fix, buff, nerf, or modify in any form, there would be a lot of problems. Some champions would be god-tier and some would not function.
-----------------------------
When you buy a movie ticket, you very much do not own that movie. What you have purchased is a limited license to a single viewing.

When you buy a physical copy of a movie, you very much do not own that movie. What you have purchased is a limited license that allows you to privately view the movie. [Some university's guidelines on showing movies](https://www.wlu.edu/general-counsel/answer-center/copyright-and-intellectual-property/copyright-guidelines-for-showing-movies-and-other-audiovisual-works), if you're interested.

If you owned the movie, then you would have the rights to stop anyone else from broadcasting it. You'd also be the only one allowed to sell the movie to other people. And many other things that come with ownership.
--------------------------------
The same laws that allow Riot to ban accounts are the ones required for them to be able to function as a game. To modify those laws carelessly would be very dangerous. If you want the laws modified, I suggest you contact your representatives in the government.

You are literally regurgitating what I told you, slick. and you are the one who implied people have access. Lemme copy/paste ya in case you forgot what you said.

"Would you rather have Riot be legally unable to modify champions? Once someone purchased it, Riot would be unable to change it.

Also, once someone purchased a champion, no one else would be able to also purchase that champion. Someone already owns it.

Can you imagine League with 150 million different champions, many of which are in a completely overpowered state, like release Zoe?"

How would someone change a champion without having said access to Riot's servers? YOU said that. Step down from that high horse.

I said that Riot would not be able to change the champions.

I did not _**previously**_ say that the owner would be able to change the champions, but with your scenario being that champions are treated by law the same as physical objects, they would be legally allowed to, and Riot could be in trouble if they tried to stop it from happening.

So my prior point was that the game would be unplayable, and my new point is that the game would be UNPLAYABLE. Could you imagine what stupid abilities and ranges people would code for their own champions?

So, your wanting champions to be treated like physical objects runs into another problem.

technically, Riot can ban you for no reason at all.

they own the game and the servers. your ability to use them is completely dependent on Riot's permission.

I mean, i wouldnt go that far. Given you can pay money to purchase things, the consumer does have a legal right to what theyve purchased, and taking away access to said things isnt something one can just up and do on a whim easily, and EULA/ToS arent legally binding documents/agreements.

The ultimate answer to all of this is "can riot ban you? Yes. Can they legally do so? No one knows, no one has gone to court over it, nor do we know the limits of what they can and can not ban for or the rights the consumer can expect".

You did not purchase actual items, you purchased a license to use those items.  You actually do not have a legal right to what you've "purchased"; Riot has just agreed to allow your use of their property for a fee.  It's not something no one knows; they absolutely can ban you for no reason, legally speaking, because no consumer rights would be violated.

Courts have recently been ruling against the idea that digital goods are only "licenses", and purchasing "licenses" in general. This means purchasing digital goods is starting to become more and more treated as purchasing a physical item, meaning you now own said item. 

Basically, courts have finally caught up to the modern age, and people cant screw over customers anymore by saying "You dont actually own the thing you own because i just gave you a license to use what you bought".

If I purchase a boat, no one else has the right to alter or sell the boat.

If you actually purchased a champion is the same manner as a physical item, then Riot would not be allowed to modify it, sell it to another player, or use it in their televised competitions. You would also have the right to use that champion in your own game, or sell the character design to a competing game.
-----------------------------
There are very good reasons that digital goods are treated differently from physical goods.
That makes no sense. The manufacturer can still sell more of those boats. Its not like they can only make one of those models and once you buy it they own the entire model line.

You got a point, but my comment would be about RIOT not being able to sell the same champion to another  player, i mean, windows do sell copies of the same edition to millions of users, same applies to champions, don't you think?

You are correct.

When you purchase Windows, you do not own it. You have purchased instead a limited license to use it.

I was explaining to Pika Fox that the laws that he doesn't like are the only ones that make sense for digital goods. In an effort to explain that, I gave an example of what would be required if those laws were like the laws for physical objects.
